110003.checkresult: Device was onboarded via VDI PowerShell Script.
110003.guidance: Please ensure best practices are implemented based on below articles: NonPresistentVDI(1) NonPresistentVDI(2) Content of Startup folder will be logged below for reference: %1.

111021.checkresult: Device does not have the minimum patch level for MDE Security Configuration Management onboarding: %1.
111021.guidance: If you intend to enable MDE Security Configuration Management then please refer to following documentation for the list of requirements: Supported Platforms.

112002.checkresult: Please note the device OS build is not supported by MDE and cannot be onboarded: %1.
112002.guidance: Please refer to this article for a list of supported Windows versions: UnSupported.

112004.checkresult: Please note the sensor on this device is not PPL protected: %1.
112004.guidance: For more information about PPL protection and why it is critical, refer to: PPL. Contact Microsoft support if issue persists.

110005.checkresult: The sensor on this device is PPL protected as expected

112020.checkresult: This device attemped to onboard through Microsoft Monitoring Agent (MMA) agent but failed as it does not support onboarding using this method.
112020.guidance: Please refer to our online documentation to understand what onboarding method is appropriate for this device's Operating System: EnvNotSupported.

121001.checkresult: Please note the device has multiple MMA (Microsoft Monitoring Agent) workspaces.
121001.guidance: If the device is onboarded to Defender for Endpoint via ASC (aka Azure Defender for servers) integration, then it is recommended to remove the MDE workspace to avoid cyber upload issues. For more information on ASC integration with Defender for Endpoint please refer to: AzureDefender.

121009.checkresult: Please note that this machine has a policy that only allows domain based trusted publishers to be added. This may interfere with MDE sensor which needs to install certificates to the Trusted Publisher store.
121009.guidance: For more information, refer to: TrustedPublishers. To avoid unexpected issues, remove the associated group policy configuration: %1 %2.

122010.checkresult: Please note that this machine is running with an outdated version of Defender Platform. Platform versions older than N-2 will no longer be supported.
122010.guidance: For more information, refer to: Antimalware platform

122011.checkresult: Please note that this machine is running with an outdated version of Defender Antivirus engine.After a new package version is released, support for the previous two versions is reduced to technical support only. Versions older than that are listed in this section, and are provided for technical upgrade support only.
122011.guidance: For more information, refer to: Antivirus engine

121012.checkresult: Please note that this machine is running with outdated security intelligence version. It is recommended to apply the most recent security intelligence vesion to ensure optimal protection and compatiblity.
121012.guidance: For more information, refer to: defenderupdates

121013.checkresult:
This test checks the signer expiration and warns if CTL are outdate. 
Your CTL has expired %1 days ago. 
See detailed output at: %2
121013.guidance: Please ensure that you update latest CTLs in file share: CertSignerAutoUpdate.

121014.checkresult:
This test checks the signer expiration and warns if CTL are outdate. 
Your CTL has expired %1 days ago. 
See detailed output at: %2
121014.guidance: Please ensure you update the CTLs via windows update or WSUS. For more information about how CTLs and how root certificate distribution works please refer to: CertSignerManualUpdate.

122003.guidance: Please ensure the mentioned missing path(s) exist and have not been renamed.  You may need to create the missing folder with system context. For example, use this command: PsExec.exe -s cmd /c (mkdir.exe %2).

122004.checkresult: This device failed to onboard via Microsoft Endpoint Configuration Manager.
122004.guidance:
This issue can happen if the regsitry key 'Windows Advanced Threat Protection' is missing from: HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\ .
 To create a missing registry key you can use: reg.exe add 'HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows Advanced Threat Protection' 
See error information from: %1.

122005.checkresult: Device is reporting to an expired Organization ID: %1.
122005.guidance: You should offboard the device from this organization, and then onboard it to your current organization. Contact Microsoft Support if you don't have access to the offboarding script with the mentioned OrgID. Note: To view the current OrgID, please go to the MDE portal (Security Center) and click on the user name in the top right corner.

122006.checkresult: Please note the device has error 'Loading the private key for the client authentication certificate' in the OpsMgr log.
122006.guidance: Please uninstall and re-install MMA (Microsoft Monitoring Agent) on this device and check if the issue persists.

122007.checkresult: The local time on the device is not matching the time in Azure.
122007.guidance: Please check that the local system time is accurate and the correct time zone is set. If this device is domain joined, please ensure that the 'Windows Time' service is running and the device is synchronized with your domain time. For more information on how to configure and control time synchronization please refer to: WindowsTime. If this device is an offline standalone device, please ensure local time in BIOS is accurate.

122008.checkresult: Device is running an older version of System Center Endpoint Protection: %1.
122008.guidance: You should upgrade to latest available version to ensure compatbility and allow malware detections to be logged in Defender for Endpoint security portal.

122015.checkresult: This machine has failed to onboard due to missing permissions for registry key HKLM_System_CurrentControlSet_Services_Sense.
122015.guidance: This can happen due to interference from 3rd party security products or if SYSTEM account full control permissions are missing for HKLM_System_CurrentControlSet_Services_Sense. The permissions found for SYSTEM account are: %1

121016.checkresult: Unable to read Service Connection Point (SCP) from Active Directory configuration partition.
121016.guidance: If you intended to implement MDE Device Configuration Management, then please refer to the following article for more information: Configure hybrid Azure Active Directory join for managed domains.

121017.checkresult: Service Connection Point (SCP) contains non-supported configuration: %1
121017.guidance: The device cannot be joined to Azure AD since the SCP record is configued to join device to Enterprise DRS.

121018.checkresult: Service Connection Point (SCP) is not configured in Active Directory configuration partition.
121018.guidance: If you intended to implement MDE Device Configuration Management, then please refer to the following article for more information: Configure hybrid Azure Active Directory join for managed domains.

121019.checkresult: Unable to connect to Domain Controller to reterive Service Connection Point (SCP) information.
121019.guidance: If you intended to implement MDE Device Configuration Management, then please refer to the following article for more information: Configure hybrid Azure Active Directory join for managed domains.

121020.checkresult: Please note that this server does not have the modern unified agent installed.
121020.guidance: Unified agent for downlevel servers is not installed on this device. It is recommended to install the new agent for optimal performance and protection capabilities. For more information refer to: Onboard Windows servers to the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint service.

120021.checkresult: The machine is assosicated with a specific AAD Tenant ID.
120021.guidance: Please ensure that the AAD Tenant ID from your MDE Tenant matches the SCP Tenant ID listed above. To see your MDE Tenant Identification refer to: M365 Security Portal

121022.checkresult: There is a discrepancy between the AAD Tenant ID from your MDE Tenant and the tenant ID in the SCP Entry of your domain.
121022.guidance: Please ensure that the AAD Tenant ID from your MDE Tenant matches the SCP Tenant ID listed above. To see your MDE Tenant Identification refer to: M365 Security Portal

122022.checkresult: Error occurred in the security configuration management flow.
122022.guidance: The device was successfully onboarded to Microsoft Defender for Endpoint. However, there was an error in the security configuration management flow. This could be due to the device not meeting the prerequisites for Microsoft Defender for Endpoint management channel.

122023.checkresult: Error occurred in the security configuration management flow.
122023.guidance: The device was successfully onboarded to Microsoft Defender for Endpoint. However, Microsoft Endpoint Manager has not been configured through the Admin Center to allow Microsoft Defender for Endpoint Security Configuration. Make sure the Microsoft Endpoint Manager tenant is configured and the feature is turned on.

122024.guidance: The device was successfully onboarded to Microsoft Defender for Endpoint. However, there was an error in the security configuration management flow which could be due to a connectivity issue. Verify that the device can communicate with Azure Active Directory and Microsoft Endpoint Manager endpoints

122025.guidance: The device was successfully onboarded to Microsoft Defender for Endpoint. However, there was an error in the security configuration management flow and the OS failed to perform hybrid join. Refer to Troubleshoot hybrid Azure Active Directory-joined devices for troubleshooting OS-level hybrid join failures.

122026.guidance: The device was successfully onboarded to Microsoft Defender for Endpoint. However, there was an error in the security configuration management flow because your Microsoft Defender for Endpoint tenant ID doesn't match your Azure Active Directory tenant ID. Make sure that the Azure Active Directory tenant ID from your Defender for Endpoint tenant matches the tenant ID in the SCP entry of your domain. For more details,. Use Troubleshoot onboarding issues related to Security Management for Microsoft Defender for Endpoint.

122027.guidance: The device was successfully onboarded to Microsoft Defender for Endpoint. However, Service Connection Point (SCP) record is not configured correctly and the device couldn't be joined to Azure AD. This could be due to the SCP being configured to join Enterprise DRS. Make sure the SCP record points to AAD and SCP is configured following best practices. For more information, see Configure a service connection point.

122028.guidance: The device was successfully onboarded to Microsoft Defender for Endpoint. However, there was an error in the security configuration management flow due to a device certificate error. The device certificate belongs to a different tenant. Verify that best practices are followed when creating trusted certificate profiles.

122029.guidance: The device was successfully onboarded to Microsoft Defender for Endpoint. However, there was an error in the security configuration management flow due to a misconfiguration in AAD Connect. To identify what is preventing the device from registering to AAD, consider running the Device Registration Troubleshooter Tool. For Windows Server 2012 R2, run the dedicated troubleshooting instructions.

122030.guidance: The device was successfully onboarded to Microsoft Defender for Endpoint. However, there was an error in the security configuration management flow due to a DNS error. Check the internet connection and/or DNS settings on the device. The invalid DNS settings might be on the workstation's side. Active Directory requires you to use domain DNS to work properly (and not the router's address). For more information, see Troubleshoot onboarding issues related to Security Management for Microsoft Defender for Endpoint.

122031.guidance: The device was successfully onboarded to Microsoft Defender for Endpoint. However, there was an error in the security configuration management flow. Verify that the clock is set correctly and is synced on the device where the error occurs.

120031.guidance: The device is managed using Configuration Manager and Microsoft Defender for Endpoint. Controlling policies through both channels may cause conflicts and undesired results. To avoid this, endpoint security policies should be isolated to a single control plane. Refer to the following URL for additional information: Co-existence with Microsoft Endpoint Configuration Manager

121035.checkresult: Device is not up-to-date and does not have anti-spoofing capability deployed.
121035.guidance: Please ensure you deploy the recommended security patch to protect the device from spoofing, for more information, please refer to: Microsoft Defender for Endpoint - CVE-2022-23278 or Microsoft Defender for Endpoint - Threat Analytics

121036.checkresult: Device is anti-spoofing capable but not in a stable state
121036.guidance: Please refer to the guidelines in the following article: Microsoft Defender for Endpoint - CVE-2022-23278 or Microsoft Defender for Endpoint - Threat Analytics Contact Microsoft support if issue persists.

120037.checkresult: Device is anti-spoofing capable and in a stable state

122038.checkresult: Device is running with an old version of the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint EDR sensor
122038.guidance: Please update the sensor to ensure you have optimal protection and stability. For more information, refer to the article: Microsoft Defender for Endpoint update for EDR Sensor

122039.checkresult:
This machine has failed to onboard due to MsSense.exe crash during initialization phase for TelLib.dll.
 The error from the crash was: %1
122039.guidance:
This can happen if the SYSTEM account does not have permissions to write to the expected path (ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\Cyber).
 Please validate the ACLs in the path and reset the permissions from parent folder if needed.

121040.checkresult: Device is anti-spoofing capable but is not yet registered with cloud.
121040.guidance: Please ensure connectivity to EDRCloud CnC URLs is not blocked. Contact Microsoft support if issue persits.

130009.checkresult: Please note this machine is not set to automatically update Trusted Root Certificates from Windows Update %1 %2.

130010.checkresult: Certificate validation for the Defender for Endpoint cloud service completed successfully.

130011.checkresult: Test connection to the Microsoft Defender Antivirus cloud service completed successfully.

130017.checkresult: Test connection to the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (CnC) cloud service URLs completed successfully.

130018.checkresult: Test connection to the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (Cyber) cloud service URLs completed successfully.

130019.checkresult: Test connection to the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (AutoIR) cloud service URLs completed successfully.

130020.checkresult: Test connection to the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (SampleUpload) cloud service URLs completed successfully.

130021.checkresult: Test connection to the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (MdeConfigMgr) cloud service URLs completed successfully.

131001.checkresult: EDR Cloud checks have not run successfully.
131001.guidance: Ensure PsExec is not blocked in your environment and then try again. If you cannot allow PsExec to be run in your environment due to security reasons, then you can try log collection via Live Response as explained here: LiveAnalyzer

131003.checkresult: The trusted root certificates cannot be updated from Windows Update. This can cause issues with Sensor CNC heartbeats or cyber data upload to cloud.
131003.guidance: You must allow access to Automatic Root Certificates Update URL. For more information, refer to: AuthRoot(1) Or, to facilitate the distribution of certificates for a disconnected environment, you must deploy a server that can download the CTL files from the automatic update mechanism: AuthRoot(2).

131004.guidance: If the device is in 'Impaired communications' status, try manually running 'certutil.exe -verify -urlfetch winatp.cer' using PsExec -s, to ensure the revocation checks are working when executed in system context. Note that both PsExec.exe and winatp.cer files are inside available inside the 'Tools' directory of the analyzer.

131005.checkresult: Cloud connectivity may be impaired due to certificate revocation failures.
131005.guidance: Please ensure the following URLs are not blocked: http://crl.microsoft.com/pki/crl and http://www.microsoft.com/pkiops. For more information please refer to ServiceURLs. For detailed error information, review %1.

131007.checkresult: Test connection to the Microsoft Defender Antivirus cloud service failed: %1
131007.guidance: If Microsoft Defender Antivirus is not in passive mode (it is operating as your primary antivirus solution) or you have opted to enable 'EDR block Mode' - please make sure connections to AV cloud URLs are not blocked: AVCloud. For more information about EDR in Block Mode please refer to: EdrBlockMode.

131013.checkresult:
Test connection to the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (CnC) cloud service URLs failed. 
The test has failed for the following URL: 
%1
131013.guidance: Please review your network configuration and ensure required URLs are not blocked. For more information refer to: ServiceURLs.

Test connection to the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (Cyber) cloud service URLs failed. 
The test has failed for the following URL:

131017.guidance: Please review your network configuration and ensure required URLs are not blocked. For more information refer to: ServiceURLs.

132006.checkresult: Cloud connectivity may be impaired due to faulty EccCurves SSL settings.
132006.guidance: If you did not intend to modify the ECC curves, please remove these group policy settings: EccCurves.

132012.checkresult: This machine has errors in EventLogs perationsManager.evtx indicating secure connection could not be negotiated in event Log.
132012.guidance: Please ensure the Trusted Root lists are correctly updated from WSUS or Windows Update. If you are manually updating Trusted Roots, please ensure you follow guidelines in KB2813430: AuthRoot.

All test connections to Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (CnC) cloud service URLs have failed.

132021.guidance: Please review your network configuration and ensure required URLs are not blocked. For more information refer to: ServiceURLs.

All test connections to Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (SampleUpload) cloud service URLs have failed.

140005.checkresult: Sensor process is protected by Exploit Protection DisableExtensionPoints.

141001.checkresult: UTC Service is Disabled. This device may not be able to upload cyber data.
141001.guidance: Make the service is not disabled by Policy. For more information refer to: DiagTrack.

141002.checkresult: DiagTrack (UTC) listener missing. This device is unable to upload cyber data.
141002.guidance:
This can happen if *.settings-win.data.microsoft.com is blocked in your network and UTC the service cannot download a 1kb config file. 
Contact Microsoft support if issue persists.

141003.guidance: This device is unable to upload cyber data. Contact Microsoft support if issue persists and you require assistance with onboarding.

142007.checkresult: DiagTrack service is unable to start. This may be caused by incompatible process MitigationOptions. Note that certain Process Mitigation options may also cause the DiagTrack listener to appear as missing.
142007.guidance:
Please try removing registry settings from below path and check if the problem persists: 
HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\kernel\MitigationOptions 
HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Image File Execution Options\svchost.exe\MitigationOptions. 
The current Kernel or SvcHost ProcessMitigation have been exported to MDEClientAnalyzerResult\SystemInfoLogs directory for reference.

142008.checkresult:
Please note this device has error ID WSAEPROVIDERFAILEDINIT in EventLogs\utc.evtx. 
This may be caused by deprecated LSPs (Layered Service Providers) installed on the system.
142008.guidance:
Windows 10 version 1809 or later has additional tamper protections that can block LSPs from interfering with our sensor. Please ensure the following or later patches are installed if issue persists: 
KB4577069 for 1809 and KB4577062 for 1903/1909.

142009.checkresult: Provider Initialization errors on this device may be cause by no longer supported Forefront TMG Client Winsock LSP.
142009.guidance:
Please uninstall TMG firewall client from the affected device and ensure the following or later patches are installed if issue persists: 
KB4577069 for 1809 and KB4577062 for 1903/1909.
